norm#

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.norm = <scipy.stats._continuous_distns.norm_gen object>#

A normal continuous random variable.

The location (loc) keyword specifies the mean. The scale (scale) keyword specifies the standard deviation.

As an instance of the rv_continuous class, norm object inherits from it a collection of generic methods (see below for the full list), and completes them with details specific for this particular distribution.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.rvs(loc=0, scale=1, size=1, random_state=None)#

Random variates.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.pdf(x, loc=0, scale=1)#

Probability density function.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.logpdf(x, loc=0, scale=1)#

Log of the probability density function.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.cdf(x, loc=0, scale=1)#

Cumulative distribution function.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.logcdf(x, loc=0, scale=1)#

Log of the cumulative distribution function.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.sf(x, loc=0, scale=1)#

Survival function (also defined as 1 - cdf, but sf is sometimes more accurate).

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.logsf(x, loc=0, scale=1)#

Log of the survival function.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.ppf(q, loc=0, scale=1)#

Percent point function (inverse of cdf — percentiles).

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.isf(q, loc=0, scale=1)#

Inverse survival function (inverse of sf).

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.moment(order, loc=0, scale=1)#

Non-central moment of the specified order.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.stats(loc=0, scale=1, moments='mv')#

Mean(‘m’), variance(‘v’), skew(‘s’), and/or kurtosis(‘k’).

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.entropy(loc=0, scale=1)#

(Differential) entropy of the RV.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.fit(data)#

Parameter estimates for generic data. See scipy.stats.rv_continuous.fit for detailed documentation of the keyword arguments.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.expect(func, args=(), loc=0, scale=1, lb=None, ub=None, conditional=False, \*\*kwds)#

Expected value of a function (of one argument) with respect to the distribution.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.median(loc=0, scale=1)#

Median of the distribution.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.mean(loc=0, scale=1)#

Mean of the distribution.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.var(loc=0, scale=1)#

Variance of the distribution.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.std(loc=0, scale=1)#

Standard deviation of the distribution.

eosdxanalysis.preprocessing.peak_finding.interval(confidence, loc=0, scale=1)#

Confidence interval with equal areas around the median.

Notes

The probability density function for norm is:

\[f(x) = \frac{\exp(-x^2/2)}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\]

for a real number \(x\).

The probability density above is defined in the “standardized” form. To shift and/or scale the distribution use the loc and scale parameters. Specifically, norm.pdf(x, loc, scale) is identically equivalent to norm.pdf(y) / scale with y = (x - loc) / scale. Note that shifting the location of a distribution does not make it a “noncentral” distribution; noncentral generalizations of some distributions are available in separate classes.

Examples

>>> from scipy.stats import norm
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)

Calculate the first four moments:

>>> mean, var, skew, kurt = norm.stats(moments='mvsk')

Display the probability density function (pdf):

>>> x = np.linspace(norm.ppf(0.01),
...                 norm.ppf(0.99), 100)
>>> ax.plot(x, norm.pdf(x),
...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='norm pdf')

Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a “frozen” RV object holding the given parameters fixed.

Freeze the distribution and display the frozen pdf:

>>> rv = norm()
>>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf')

Check accuracy of cdf and ppf:

>>> vals = norm.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999])
>>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], norm.cdf(vals))
True

Generate random numbers:

>>> r = norm.rvs(size=1000)

And compare the histogram:

>>> ax.hist(r, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2)
>>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False)
>>> plt.show()
